results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Mountains of Mystery’, contains a trip around The Grampians National Park in Victoria. The filmmaker captures the various activities of visitors to the Grampians area as well as views across the mountains, an occasional bee, lizard, snake and echidna, trees, bush and wildflowers as well as the overall rocky terrain.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Mountains of Mystery’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:22:00 hikers on top of a huge log across a creek.
00:01:57:00 an echidna hiding in the bush.
00:02:05:00 hikers walking along a bush track.
00:07:20:00 instruction card for walkers and hikers.
00:07:55:00 sign to various locations in the Park.
00:08:06:00 hikers climbing up trails and narrow ravines among dramatic grey rocky outcrops followed by views from the summit.
00:09:57:00 a koala asleep in a tree
00:10:02:00 an intrepid hiker perched precariously on a high narrow rock ledge
00:10:39:00 plaque for ‘Makefing Reserve’ near the Grampians
00:11:00:00 signpost for ‘Makefing Rd’ (in two directions) and ‘Emmet Rd’ and ‘Stockyard…’ (which could be a sign to ‘Stockyard Hill’
00:11:19:00 park sign for ‘Major Mitchell Plateau’, ‘Mt William’, ‘Jimmy Creek’
00:12:29:00 hikers preparing a couple of ‘billy cans’ of tea and/or food on a small open fire
00:12:59:00 a hiker in all red gear including a woollen cap with a ‘pom pom’
00:13:45:00 scenes of hikers on steep tracks and then views from the summit
00:15:12:00 hikers gather around a boiling ‘billy’ on a small fire
00:15:40:00 sitting enjoying their tea
00:16:25:00 and echidna hiding in the grass
00:16:37:00 tree ferns followed by an old, plank footbridge over a creek
00:16:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’

results.brief_description:

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Orchid Isle’, ‘A WHC Film’

00:01:36:00 Fijian musicians wearing elaborate floral costumes performing in an outdoor setting.
00:02:10:00 Fijian style thatched houses.
00:03:01:00 turtle swimming.
00:04:55:00 tourists participating in cultural performance.
00:05:35:00 palm weaving being shown to tourists.
00:06:51:00 passengers onboard a ferry listening to local musicians.
00:09:43:00 large ship at port in Suva.
00:10:18:00 local traffic in Suva.
00:10:30:00 marching military band in Suva.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’

00:01:05:00 buffalo

00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.

results.description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 close-up of a moth on a leaf
00:00:38:00 large mushrooms in a grassy paddock
00:00:46:00 a woman slicing the mushrooms from the ground and collecting in a bucket
00:01:07:00 a largish spider runs up a canvas tent wall and the underside of a mushroom
00:01:22:00 peeling a large mushroom
00:01:52:00 a Coolabah brand wine cask and a poodle dog, mushrooms cooked on a camp stove
00:02:10:00 climbing over a stile in a fence
00:02:53:00 hikers climbing and helping each other over a rocky part of the trail
00:03:07:00 close-up of a spider in its web
00:04:07:00 descending a steep rock face
00:05:49:00 a iridescent blue and green beetle, tree lichen and a brown spider in its web
00:06:09:00 perfect light brown mushroom soon followed by another species of mushroom
00:06:54:00 several spiders on their webs
00:07:42:00 a variety of leather mushrooms
00:08:30:00 likely Ambicodamus crinitus spider
00:09:13:00 sign ‘Werribee Gorge’
00:09:30:00 hikers group sitting on the edge of a rocky cliff looking at the view, including a woman with binoculars
00:11:18:00 koala in close-up and and then climbing a tree
00:11:40:00 soaring Australian wedge-tailed eagle
00:12:07:00 group of (likely) bombadier beetles in green leaves
00:12:52:00 crossing the creek rock by rock
00:13:05:00 a small brown frog (likely litoria paraewingi)
00:13:12:00 hikers take a break - cameras, snacks and beer
00:15:02:00 overlooking tents at the camping site
00:15:17:00 wading the creek and a hiker rests with his dog on a hillside
00:15:55:00 leaf impressions on the rocks
00:16:36:00 1970s style cars - station wagons and camping van
00:16:55:00 two men using a manual post hole digger followed by scenes of fence making
00:17:29:00 planting new trees

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’

00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.
